com.futurice.cascade.reactive.ui

Class ReactiveImageView

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.view.View
      • android.widget.ImageView
        • com.futurice.cascade.reactive.ui.ReactiveImageView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.graphics.drawable.Drawable.Callback, android.view.accessibility.AccessibilityEventSource, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, INamed, IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>

    public class ReactiveImageView
extends android.widget.ImageView
implements IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>
    An ImageView which can be directly bound to change the screen when an up-chain value changes

      Remove all up-chain branches from this node of the reactive function tree
      void unsubscribeSource(java.lang.String reason, IReactiveSource<android.graphics.Bitmap> reactiveSource)
      Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.

    • Method Detail

      • fire

        public void fire(@nonnull
                 android.graphics.Bitmap bitmap)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        An upchain IReactiveSource is notifying us of a new input value to process. You don't usually call the fire methods directly. They are called for you when this is an input or state change, for example by ReactiveValue.set(Object)

        Nodes within a reactive chain may choose to be stateless such as Subscription.

        Nodes at the leaf of a reactive chain will typically retain this value as state, for example (ReactiveValue).

        They may also choose to otherwise create a stateful side effect with the value received. The recommended practice is to not create such side effects except in the leaf node(s) at the end of chain branches. If you violate this rule, be warned you tend to end up with a hairy memory management and partially-completed-stateful-logic-before-exception error correction mess.

        If you would like to unlink this object when the fire operation results in an error, you must do so in an .mOnError() statement lower down in the chain you wish to trigger such an action.

        Specified by:
        fire in interface IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>
        Parameters:
        bitmap - The value from the previous link in the reactive chain.

      • fireNext

        public void fireNext(@nonnull
                     android.graphics.Bitmap bitmap)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Same as IReactiveTarget.fire(Object) however this is queued LIFO for more immediate execution. You do not generally call this directly. Chains call this for you. It is called instead of IReactiveTarget.fire(Object) mid-chain to reduce work in progress and complete the task tree is an depth-first manner. This reduces the latency of individual chains once execution starts. It also decreases the peak memory load by more rapidly flushing intermediate values to the leaf node side effects of the chain.
        Specified by:
        fireNext in interface IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>

      • setImageURI

        public void setImageURI(@nonnull
                        android.net.Uri uri)
        Description copied from class: android.widget.ImageView
        Sets the content of this ImageView to the specified Uri.

        This does Bitmap reading and decoding on the UI thread, which can cause a latency hiccup. If that's a concern, consider using ImageView.setImageDrawable(android.graphics.drawable.Drawable) or ImageView.setImageBitmap(android.graphics.Bitmap) and BitmapFactory instead.

        Overrides:
        setImageURI in class android.widget.ImageView
        Parameters:
        uri - The Uri of an image

      • subscribeSource

        public void subscribeSource(@nonnull
                            java.lang.String reason,
                            @nonnull
                            IReactiveSource<android.graphics.Bitmap> reactiveSource)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will start sending updates This allows the target which is responsible for holding a strong reference to the source to prevent it from being garbage collected until all targets of a given source go out of scope and are themselves garbage collected. You may manually speed this process by calling IReactiveTarget.unsubscribeSource(String, IReactiveSource), however if you choose not to or forget to do so, it will be taken care of for you fairly soon.
        Specified by:
        subscribeSource in interface IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>

      • unsubscribeSource

        public void unsubscribeSource(@nonnull
                              java.lang.String reason,
                              @nonnull
                              IReactiveSource<android.graphics.Bitmap> reactiveSource)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.
        Specified by:
        unsubscribeSource in interface IReactiveTarget<android.graphics.Bitmap>

      • unsubscribeAllSources

        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Remove all up-chain branches from this node of the reactive function tree
        Specified by:

      • onDetachedFromWindow

        public void onDetachedFromWindow()
        Description copied from class: android.view.View
        This is called when the view is detached from a window. At this point it no longer has a surface for drawing.
        Overrides:
        onDetachedFromWindow in class android.widget.ImageView
